abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Industrial
            Development Project for Sri Lanka was satisfactory. The
            project achieved its main objectives, its impact on
            institutional development has been substantial,
            sustainability is likely, and both the Bank and Borrower
            performed satisfactorily. Several lessons can be learned
            from this project. First, one of the key factors that
            affects the sustainability of an intermediation operation is
            the financial viability and sustainability of the credit
            institutions, which is also affected by their internal
            operational efficiency as well as the policy and regulatory
            framework in which they operate. Satisfactory loan
            collection performance reflects the internal operational
            efficiency of DFIs and is a major indicator of program
            sustainability. Second, effective monitoring and supervision
            of the project by both IDA and the Government was integral
            to the success of the project. Finally, the design of the TA
            is critical for the effective implementation of a project.
